docs.title: Home
docs.text:
The world of Arcadia is made up of islands that float in the air. The islands are suspended in midair by powerful Elemental Crystals that lie at the core of the land. These elemental crystals infuse the islands, affecting the people, climate, and resources available there. There are ten elementally influenced areas, though the forces at play mean that not all have people living on them.

First, an above the table note on the setting. Not required reading, but may be helpful for understanding why the setting is how it is.

This is a work in progress. More Pages and links to those pages will appear over time

Arcadia has a reasonably deep Timeline of events, and a simple Calendar System.

docs.title: The Floating Continents
docs.text: Ten large floating continents hover over a Void Below, each elementally charged. Airships are the only way of travel between continents.

docs.title: Acid Wastes
docs.text:
• Element: Acid
  • Associated Color: Purple
  • People: None
  • Terrain: Blasted rock, acid pools
  • Government: None

The acid wastes are an extremely inhospitable rocky plains, with pools of acidic water fed by frequent acid rains. Clouds of toxic gas rise from the rock at random, and monsters stalk the terrain, looking for food. The only sign of civilization here is an ancient, magically-reinforced abandoned penitentiary on the northern coast that no extant nation takes credit for.

docs.title: Brunhild
docs.text:
• Element: Lightning
  • Associated Color: Yellow
  • People: Dwarf, Polder
  • Terrain: Mountainous, rough (settlements are uniformly subterranean)
  • Government: Multi-Level Elected Representative councils

Brunhild is a prosperous, technologically advanced country that thrives under near-constant lightning storms. A few hundred years ago, the people here found a way to harness the lightning and use it to power immensely complicated machines and weapons. This drove a technological revolution here - nearly limitless free energy allowed an amazingly rapid industrialization of most manual labor, allowing a generation of tinkerers and inventors to spring up. For safety, the people here primarily live in large excavated cave systems, strongholds carved from the mountains and made into beautiful, strong homes.

docs.title: Celestia
docs.text:
• Element: Holy
  • Associated Color: White
  • People: Very diverse, humans most common.
  • Terrain: Grasslands, Woodlands
  • Government: in flux

Celestia is the country of the gods and of religion. One of the more metropolitan countries, people of all types live here, including what many would term the "monstrous" races. Currently in the midst of a revolution, the political situation, especially in the capital, is tenuous. People here live primarily in wattle and daub houses, though stone or log houses are not uncommon in the wilds.

docs.title: Frostlands
docs.text:
• Element: Cold
  • Associated Color: Blue
  • People: Dragon Knight, Hakaan
  • Terrain: Tundra, Glacier, Ice
  • Government: Tribal, loosely associated

The frostlands are made up of not so much islands as glaciers or icebergs. The blue icy elemental crystal causes nearly constant snowfall in the frostlands, snow that almost never melts. This accumulation requires the people of these lands to have to take significant action in order to keep from being inundated. Only recently have the tribes of the frostlands began unifying under the banner of one Hadren Greyscale, a Dragon Knight of advanced age and wisdom. Homes and buildings in the Frostlands are primarily wooden construction, with leather or hide wrappings to keep the heat in.

docs.title: Hollows
docs.text:
• Element: Psychic
  • Associated Color: Orange
  • People: Varied
  • Terrain: Rolling Hills, Ruined Metropolis
  • Government: None

Until very recently, The Hollows was largely inaccessible due to a persistent psychic storm that blanketed the area influenced by the Orange crystal. This effect, it turned out, was due to an eldritch monstrosity that had taken the area as a lair. At the end of the 100-hours war, the death of the monstrosity ended the storm. The repercussions of the war and the monstrosity are still being felt here, but the previously isolated population is recovering, and the location is a favorite for researchers and adventurers.

docs.title: Pyrrhus
docs.text:
• Element: Fire
  • Associated Color: Red
  • People: Human, Dwarf
  • Terrain: Desert, Mountains
  • Government: Hereditary Monarchy

Pyrrhus is a mountainous, desert island with a large, active volcano at the center. The mountainous terrain has significant metal and firestone deposits, and is prosperous as a result. Pyrrhus suffered most after the 100-hours war, when many of the top politicians and buracrats were revealed to have been under control of the Abomination from the hollows. The new king, thankfully, is well liked and was spared any blowback from his father's corruption. Most buildings in Pyrrhus are of mud brick or mortared stone, for insulation from the desert heat.

docs.title: Silvius
docs.text:
• Element: Poison
  • Associated Color: Green
  • People: Wode Elves
  • Terrain: Dense Forest
  • Government: Constitutionally Limited Monarchy

Silvius is a dense jungle, full of predatory animals, poisonous and carnivorous plants, and a thriving society of wode elves. The crystal powering Silvius taints the land with poison, requiring innovative farming techniques from the Silvian People to produce safe food. It is here that floatwood, a light, strong material used mainly in airship construction is found in great quantities, giving Silvius a strong trade position and relatively powerful navy. The people here live in tree houses above the jungle floor, in great cities connected by bridges and ladders.

docs.title: Thellonde
docs.text:
• Element: Corruption
  • Associated Color: Black
  • People: High Elves
  • Terrain: Grasslands, Forests
  • Government: Monarchy

Thellonde is a powerful elvish kingdom that lives in a land where the dead occasionally rise from their graves if not properly handled. The people here are known as skilled craftsmen and artists, using their long lives to perfect their crafts. Thellonde claims to have "conquered death", with the ritual that allows them to raise the honored dead as deathless. These deathless retain their personality and selves, but do not age. Thellonde can raise a significant army at a moments notice though the use of these deathless, making them possibly the most militarily powerful nation in Arcadia.

docs.title: The Thundering Storm
docs.text:
• Element: Sonic
  • Associated Color: Clear
  • People: None
  • Terrain: Small islands, rocky
  • Government: None

The Thundering Storm is a vast area of cyclones, high winds, flying debris, and other dangers. There are a few settlement worthy islands on the borders of the Storm, and they are almost all populated by pirates, brigands, and other lowlifes. No country claims the thundering storm, as even if there were valuable resources here, it would be difficult to extract them. There was once a continent and powerful empire here, before the Calamity Event changed things.

docs.title: Xelsoan
docs.text:
• Element: Gravity, Force
  • Associated Color: Silver
  • People: Varied
  • Terrain: Plains, Hills, Mountains
  • Government: Representative Democracy

A quirk of physics caused by the elemental crystal at the center of Xelsoan allows the people here to create perpetual energy machines. This has led to a technological revolution here, with effectively free mechanical energy being used to power everything from water pumps to mechanical guardians. Xelsoan is a metropolitan place - probably the most well-mixed country in all of Arcadia, and practically every even semi-civilized race is represented here. This mixing of people, ideas, and plentiful energy has allowed Xelsoan to be one of the most socially and technologically advanced countries in Arcadia.

docs.title: The People
docs.text: In the Arcadian setting, some Ancestries have slightly different lore than as written in the Draw Steel: Heroes book. Additionally, there are some extra Ancestries that one could choose.

docs.title: Devil
docs.text: Largely as default. There are enough Devils on Arcadia that are second, third, or later generation native Arcadians that most people do not assume a given Devil has any connection to the Seven Cities of Hell. Found all throughout Arcadia.

docs.title: Dragon Knight (Dragonkin)
docs.text: Rather than a result of a ritual, Dragonkin are a normal, if slowly breeding species. Mostly isolated to the Frostlands, many Arcadians go their whole life without seeing a Dragonkin.

docs.title: Dwarf
docs.text: As book default. Found primarily in Brunhild, and Pyrrhus

docs.title: Wode Elf
docs.text: Largely as book default. In modern times, the Wode Elves of Silvius are no longer reclusive or known for 'snatching children'.

docs.title: High Elf
docs.text: Associated primarily with Thellonde, the high elves of Arcadia are the originators of the ritual capable of creation of Deathless.

docs.title: Hakaan
docs.text: Largely as written. Found primarily in the Frostlands

docs.title: Humans
docs.text: As written. Found Everywhere.

docs.title: Memonek
docs.text: Mostly as written, but extremely rare. The Memonek were unknown a century ago, but have been appearing with more and more frequency. Often appear in Arcadia proper because they were sent on a specific quest by "higher beings"

docs.title: Orc
docs.text: Largely as written. Orcs are a people in diaspora, forming communities within all the various countries. Once leaders of the Baranthean Empire, before it's fall.

docs.title: Polder
docs.text: Polder are not as well integrated in human societies, being more closely intertwined with dwarfish society. There are Polder groups everywhere, but the largest is in Brunhild, followed closely by Pyrrhus.

docs.title: Revenant (but also Deathless)
docs.text: A true Revenant is rare, but do exist in Arcadia. Significantly more common are the Deathless of Thellonde, which are commonly "created" by ritual by the government there. See the Deathless page for details. Both use the same ancestry rules. Deathless from ancestries that are not High Elfs are rare.

docs.title: Time Raider
docs.text:
Time Raiders are currently unknown on Arcadia, though there are a few places they could appear. If you wish to play a Time Raider, ask!

Catfolk The Catfolk of Arcadia are known for their shrewd business sense and are most commonly found in Xelsoan

docs.title: Catfolk
docs.text: If you wish to play a Catfolk, we'll find a homebrew for it.

docs.title: Deathless
docs.text:
The Deathless are, in many respects, extremely similar to the Revenant (using the Revenant rules for character creation). However, rather than being brought back "through a combination of an unjust death and a burning desire for vengeance", the Deathless are brought back through well-understood (though largely secret) ritual.

The ritual to create a deathless is held closely by the noble families of Thellonde. They have, thus far, kept the number of non-Thell Deathless to a very small number, though careful decision of who is allowed to understand the ritual, and perhaps some more underhanded means.

docs.title: Differences
docs.text: The prime difference between a Deathless and a naturally-formed Revenant is the requirement for a Deathless to hold a small sliver of black Elemental Crystal on their person at all times. Without this, a Deathless will slowly lose the animating energy keeping it going. After some time, usually weeks to months, depending on the particular Deathless, the individual will fall unconscious. In this state, a Deathless does not perceive the flow of time, and rests as if a perfectly preserved corpse, until a new shard of black crystal is brought to them. A comatose Deathless that is given a shard of black crystal wakes within a few days, returning to peak form as if their animating force had never been missing.

docs.title: Acid Wastes
docs.text:
The Acid Wastes is aptly named. A barren, hostile rock, the pools of concentrated acid, corrosive rain, and minimal natural resources make this place an undesirable destination

Basic Stats Crystal Color Purple Element Acid

docs.title: Abandoned Penitentiary
docs.text: This magically reinforced stone and metal building hides an entrance to a surprisingly deep cave system within the rocks of the Acid Wastes. The cave system is dug out in such a way as to be part maze, part prison. Research done to determine the age of the penitentiary returns dates that vary from 300 to about 600 BC.

docs.title: Brunhild
docs.text:
Brunhild is a continent where the surface is constantly blasted by lightning, resulting in the clans of Dwarves and Polder here bunkering down in sprawling cavern cities dug out of the rock of the continent. Within, they research, and brew, and drink, and generally push the overall level of technological innovation of Arcadia forward, one explosion at a time.

Basic Stats Capital Gareholm Demonym Brun, Brunhildi Government System Multi-Level Representative Democracy Head of State Magne Eliassen Exports Chargestone, Metals, Alcohol Imports Food, Wood Crystal Color Yellow Element Lightning

docs.title: Demography and Population
docs.text: 50% Dwarf, 30% Polder, 10% Goblinoid, 10% Other The people of Brunhild are a hard working, industrious lot, especially since the Chargestone-fueled industrial revolution several hundred years ago. During the day, forges are stoked, research is done, and alcohol is brewed. At night, the people here enjoy the fruits of their labors, drinking and partying. Then they repeat the whole thing over the next day. Unfortunately, mixing the large reserves of chargestone power and experimental technology with drinking and partying often leads to accidental building demolition, fireworks, or more often, thick black columns of smoke. The next morning, the people all pitch in together to get the affected property owner back into working shape. The clan mentality helps here, as even those not responsible for the destruction help with the rebuild. It is usually only a matter of hours or days before any destroyed building is back to functional - and probably better than it was the first time.

docs.title: Government Structure
docs.text: Brunhild has a two-level representative democracy system. Towns, Villages, Cities and the like each have a council of clans that meets locally to handle local affairs. From each of these councils, a representative is elected and sent to Gareholm to represent them in the Great Council. The Great Council votes on matters of state and external affairs, weighing each vote by the size of the population center represented.

docs.title: Military
docs.text: Brunhild's Military is a "Purely Defensive Force" to hear the Great Council speak of it. Brunhild's cities, being almost uniformly underground, are extremely defensible, and the people in general have very little appetite for fighting. The force of Brunhild is significantly smaller than those of most other countries, but more elite, and their war-airships have more firepower and are better armored than those built elsewhere.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text: Artrix is the most worshipped of the major gods here, their portfolio of learning and magic fitting well with the enthusiastic researchers of Brunhild.

docs.title: Agriculture & Industry
docs.text: Brunhild's Industry is primarily based on chargestone - the production and charging of it, and the subsequent use of it to power complex, powerful machines. Chargestone acts quite a bit like a battery, allowing electric engines, powerful new types of weapons, and other impressive new technologies. The export of chargestones is profitable, but limited, as the government wishes to ensure that Brunhild retains the competitive advantage of cheap, easy electrical power. Powered by the chargestone, Brunhild is a technological powerhouse, creating impressive new kinds of weapons, ships, and devices to make life easier. Brunhild's minor industries are metals and alcohol. The rocky, mountainous terrain holds significant deposits of some rare metals, Adamantine and Mithril, plus the more valuable base metals, like Silver and Gold, and the people of Brunhild are avid brewers. Some of the best drinks in the world are brewed here.

docs.title: Education
docs.text: Brunhild's strong social support systems ensure a high level of education is available to every Brunhildi child. Upper education is via either formal colleges in the larger cities of Brunhild, or through apprenticeships with those working in the desired industry.

docs.title: Technological Level
docs.text: One of the most technologically advanced countries in Arcadia, Brunhild holds a monopolistic edge on chargestone, and therefore, electrically powered conveniences. Although many of the most popular chargestone tools are replicable with Crystal Ritual magic, the chargestone version is simpler and easier for the average person to use.

docs.title: Celestia
docs.text:
Celestia is the country of the gods. A place where each of the Gods, small and large has large temples and

Basic Stats Capital Gods' Watch Demonym Celestian Government System In Flux Head of State N/A Exports Religion, Minerals/Ores Imports Food Crystal Color White Element Holy

docs.title: Demography and Population
docs.text: 37% Human, 22% Polder, 18% Elf, 10% Dwarf, 13% Other. Celestia is a fairly well mixed country, with representatives from many races, including some of the more monstrous races. Many of the more powerful temples (Pyros , Yrrasil and Imera, in particular) teach their followers to be accepting of others, so these godly lands are quite accepting of all who live here.

docs.title: Government Structure
docs.text: Until quite recently, the Celestian government was a two-house system where a Circle of mages were one house, while the other held elected officials of the various churches. The notably divergent desires of these two groups caused constant deadlock and a generally weak country that had trouble getting anything done. After decades of their government being largely useless, the frustration of the people of Celestia finally boiled over two years ago in a revolution that is still ongoing. The mages of The Circle have largely fled Celestia for more welcoming lands, while the churches attempt to hold what power they can while weathering the people's ire. The People's Rebellion is starting to cool, now that the members of The Circle have left, leaving the leaders of the rebellion to figure out how to lead an actual country.

docs.title: Military
docs.text: Even before the People's Rebellion, the Celestian army was weak, and The Rebellion has further weakened Celestian military power. Perhaps thankfully, Celestia is poor in natural resources, and there's very little reason for other nations to take advantage of the current state of disarray.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text: All the major gods, and the majority of the less important gods of Arcadia keep their center of power here. The most devout worshipers of the various churches are found here or travel here in order to rise up the ranks of their church. Walking the streets of the larger Celstian towns can be an overwhelming affair, as it is extremely common for street corners to be occupied by preachers attempting to convert passers by to whatever deity they worship. This has been less common in recent years, as the fall of the previous government means the churches are less in contention with each other to secure votes in the conclave of churches.

docs.title: Agriculture & Industry
docs.text: Celestian lands are not particularly suitable for farming. The rocky soil here is poor in nutrients, but rich in minerals both magical and mundane. Mining is one of the prime industries, and the magical materials that come from Celestia's quarries often stay in-nation to be sent to the churches to make magical or holy objects that are then sold off for a high premium. Celestian healing potions, for example, are the standard against which those crafted elsewhere are judged.

docs.title: Education
docs.text: Celestian education follows a reasonably familiar model: free state mandated lower education, and a system of self-paid higher education institutions. Celestians out of the state mandated lower education system are ready to enter many available jobs, and the system does a good job of finding those with, for example, innate magical talents, or the like.

docs.title: Technological Level
docs.text: Technologically, Celestia is behind in some areas - without the natural magical environment for something like for Wound Springs from Xelsoan, or Chargestone from Brunhild, Celestia largely gets by on Crystal Ritual magic and technological imports.

docs.title: Frostlands
docs.text:
The Frostlands are made up of not so much islands as glaciers or icebergs. The blue icy elemental crystal causes nearly constant snowfall, which almost never melts, accumulating in drifts, and needing to be shoveled out of the towns. The frostlands are a tribal peoples, and only in the last several years have they begun unifying into a real nation.

Basic Stats Capital Fishtooth Mountain Demonym Frostlander Government System Loose Tribal Confederacy Head of State Hadren Greyscale Exports N/A Imports N/A

docs.title: Demography and Population
docs.text: 50% Dragonkin, 30% Hakaan, 20% Other Largely the home of Dragonkin and Hakaan, the Frostlands are a tribal peoples, mostly living in villages less than two hundred people. The various villages of the Frostlands love festivals, and often throwing a festival means not just a party for those of the village, but also of those from nearby villages. This helps keep relations friendly and promotes trade between villages.

docs.title: Government Structure
docs.text: In recent years, the people of the Frostlands have begun to unify under the chief of the tribe that lived on Fishtooth Mountain, Hadren Greyscale, a charismatic Dragonkin that rose to prominence rather suddenly. She has been working on unifying the various tribes of the Frostlands under a single banner, partially on the hopes of establishing diplomatic and trade relations with the rest of Arcadia.

docs.title: Military
docs.text: The Frostlands lack a standing military of any sort. Each tribe largely defends itself from the threats of monsters separately.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text: People of the Frostlands often revere minor gods of ice, hunting/fishing, or the like. Usually a village will have a shrine or two, but nothing extravagant. For the people of the Frostlands, religion is less important than survival - though the holy days of the gods provide ample opportunities for festivals.

docs.title: Agriculture & Industry
docs.text: The various tribes of the frostlands mostly make their livings ice fishing, trading with outsiders, and small farms. Most more complicated industries are small or not present at all.

docs.title: Education
docs.text: There is no formal education system in the Frostlands. The children of a tribe are often taught together in one large class by an elder of the tribe.

docs.title: Thellonde
docs.text:
Thellonde is a powerful elvish kingdom that lives in a land where the dead occasionally rise from their graves if not properly handled. The people here are known as skilled craftsmen and artists. Thellonde claims to have "conquered death", with the ritual that allows them to raise the honored dead as Deathless. These deathless retain their personality and selves, but do not age. Thellonde can raise a significant army at a moments notice though the use of these deathless, making them possibly the most militarily powerful nation in Arcadia.

Basic Stats Capital Highmount Demonym Thell Government System Monarchy Head of State Ellarial Alathil Exports Art, Precious Gems, Furniture Imports Food, Firestone, Raw Materials

docs.title: Demography and Population
docs.text: 80% High Elf, 10% Human,10% Other (About 10% of the High Elf population is deathless.)   Thellonde is a society where the living and dead co-mingle in peace. The high quantity of Deathless here has led to a society that is very accepting of death and the undead. The common folk of Thellonde count themselves lucky if they have a deathless ancestor or friend to advise them, and noble families usually have several deathless ancestors who advise the current heads of house and maintain traditions and ceremony.

docs.title: Government Structure
docs.text: Thellonde is a hereditary monarchy, with a ruling bloodline unbroken for centuries. The Alathil family rules as kings and queens, and is advised by The Undying Council, a group of more than twenty deathless former kings and queens of Thellonde. Besides them, there are the Noble houses - families that have rendered some exceptional service to the crown. The current queen of Thellonde is Ellarial Alathil

docs.title: Military
docs.text: The Fist of Thellonde is likely the most powerful single military force on Arcadia, as they are able to draw upon significant deathless reserves within days of battle breaking out. Beneath the capitol of Highmount, there is an enormous crypt complex, where there reside thousands of inert Deathless, who have taken the "Black Shard" option. Technically, the military has no political power, and receives orders from the monarchy directly, but they do have significant social influence.

docs.title: The Black Shard
docs.text: This social program is nominally meant to help uplift families, but is a large driver of the size of the Thell military. An individual pledges themselves to the Fist of Thellonde, and is willingly turned deathless. They then inter themselves in the crypts, setting aside the black shard within reach, but not within touch. The family draws a stipend from the "work" of the resting Deathless, and the deathless awaits the call of battle.

docs.title: Religion
docs.text: Religion is important in Thellonde, but not a daily part of life for most people. Many worship Imera, but worship of smaller gods is fairly common. Generally, people here are devout enough keep the rites and holidays, but not much more. Many in Thellonde practice something akin to ancestor worship, though no particular ancestor receives enough worship to ascend to godhood.

docs.title: Agriculture & Industry
docs.text: Thellonde is known for both gemstone mines and extremely skilled craftsmen. The mines of Thellonde are rich in gems, but do not have an appreciable quantity of metals. The craftsmen are renowned for their skill in woodworking, particularly furniture, and jewelry crafting. An heirloom table from Thellonde can be safely assumed to last many generations.

docs.title: Education
docs.text: There are two classes of education within Thellonde. Noble born and the children of well-to-do merchants often retain the services of a tutor or tutors. Otherwise, the upper-class children will often attend a private boarding school where they are educated in both the practical (math, sciences, magic) and the less practical (courtly behavior, etc). Children of lesser means enroll in a royally-mandated public schooling system, which usually does an adequate job of preparing the children for their lives.

docs.title: Technological Level
docs.text: Thellonde is known for artisans and craftsmen, not researchers, but this ignores Thellonde's deep research into ritual magic. The ritualists in Thellonde are very powerful, but keep their knowledge secret. The ritual allowing creation of a Deathless, for example, is tightly held, and there are whispers that the Deathless Ritual isn't even the most impressive arcane feat developed here.

docs.title: Void Below
docs.text:
The void below is a dark mass of swirling clouds and vortices far below the various floating continents. The winds, blown debris, and wild magic of this layer of the sky constitutes and effectively impassible barrier. No ship, research vessel, or individual has ever passed beneath the Void Below and returned. Contact with the void below shreds ships to pieces nearly as fast as they can lower (or, more often, fall) in.

Every decade or so, some brilliant scientist or researcher claims to have discovered an alloy, or an enchantment, or something that would allow passage through to whatever is below. None have yet succeeded.

docs.title: Days And Months
docs.text:
The Calendar in Arcadia is set with eight months of exactly 30 days. Between each month is a non-numbered festival day, leading to a year of 248 days.

Different cultures in Arcadia care more or less about the various festival days, and observe them in their own ways. For example, Pyrrhus celebrates the Summer's End Season Change Festival at the end of Summer quite a bit, as it marks the end of the worst of the heat there. On the other hand, Silvius celebrates most strongly the Spring Festival, as it marks the start of the planting season and the start of new life.

docs.text:
What follows is a timeline of the most important events of international import.

Loss of airship technology in the fall left the various continents isolated 1,500 BC Rediscovery of Airship Technology A century or so of rapid innovation led to a return to international travel and commerce 1,000 BC to 500 BC Rise of the Baranthean Empire Based out of what is now The Thundering Storm, the Baranthean empire was an imperialist force that took nominal control over the various other nations. 20 BC to 0 Unrest in Baranthean Empire A number of rebellions, both within the borders of the empire and the various vassal states strain the Empire's ability to control their lands. 0 The Calamity Event A destructive event that entirely removed the continent that was once at the center of The Thundering Storm, and shattered the empire. about 3 ACE to 100 ACE Rise of new continental countries With their previous imperial control missing, continent-spanning countries begin forming in the power vacuum 3254 100-hours war A war caused by an extradimensional being that resided in the Hollows 3305 Current Day

docs.title: Elemental Crystal
docs.text: The phrase "Elemental Crystal" refers to a magically infused crystalline object that radiates strongly in a single element. Each crystal has unique properties and uses, depending on the color, grade, and size of crystal. In general, using the magical effects of a crystal will eventually result in a Dun Crystal, which is inert and largely useless.

docs.title: Continental Crystal
docs.text: A continental crystal is the largest form of crystal, formed of hundreds of cubic kilometers of uniform crystal. These sit at the center of the continent-islands of Arcadia, and provide the magical force that keeps the continents floating above the Void Below. In almost all civilized places, mining or removing chunks from the Continental Crystal is a grave crime, as it risks the stability of the entire continent. Nevertheless, the value of such pure crystal, easily available, is a tempting target for those in need of quick money and with loose scruples.

docs.title: Greater Crystal
docs.text:
A greater crystal is one that is large enough to be difficult to carry by hand. Naturally forming in pockets and geodes near the Continental Crystal, Greater Crystals are often mined by the ruling government as trade goods, and can go for large sums of money in the right market. Many independent mercantile airships make their money shuffling Greater Crystals around Arcadia, selling a crystal from far away and buying local crystals with some of the profits, before moving on to wherever they think they can get the best price for their newly purchased goods.

A particularly large Greater Crystal can form the core of an Airship's lift enchantment. In this use, thankfully, a crystal does not discharge over time.

docs.title: Lesser Crystal
docs.text: Small enough to hold in hand, these crystals can rarely be found simply lying around in sufficiently untraveled areas. More often, a Greater Crystal is processed into a large number of Lesser Crystals for use by individuals to power artifice, magical items, or as reagents in various spells and rituals.

docs.title: Dun Crystal
docs.text: A crystal which has been drained of it's inherent magic turns to a crumbly, chalk-like grey stone. The crushed crystal can be further used in some rare situations, but often a Dun Crystal is simply discarded.

docs.title: Airship
docs.text:
Arcadian Airships are kept aloft by the very same Elemental Crystals that keep the islands floating.

Unfortunately, this provides lift only, and not propulsion. This leaves quite a bit of leeway for the various countries and shipyards to put their own spin on how to move the airship.

Pyrrhus in particular, is a fan of bound fire or air elementals, which form a ring around the ship and acts somewhat as a jet engine (as airships from the Eberron D&D setting) While Xelsoan-based airships carefully manipulate gravity for the hull, and hull only, of the ship, allowing for a quite comfortable ride and a more "Traditional" look.

Some lower-cost airships use sails and masts, as we would expect of sailing (water) ships.

In general, however, a ship can be of most shapes and sizes, from two to three person skiffs, to warships requiring dozens of crewmembers to sail effectively. The various shipyards have tells as to their construction, and one can usually spot where a ship is from based on it's design.

In practice, airships are extremely safe. The magic of the Elemental Crystal keeps them afloat with every minimal maintenance, and most ships have secondary sails or propulsion methods to get to a port in case of emergency. Hundreds and hundreds of airships fill the skies of Arcadia, shipping goods, transporting people, and, sometimes, ferrying adventurers from one crisis to the next.

docs.title: Firestone
docs.text: Firestone is a slightly-glowing, deep-red rocky ore mined in the mountains of Pyrrhus. It is dangerous to mine, thanks to the flammability of the raw ore. Mining and refinement of Firestone is one of the cornerstones of Pyrrhan economics.

docs.title: Raw Firestone
docs.text: This deep red ore is akin to coal, burning slowly and releasing large quantities of heat. It is used around Arcadia for heat, to power steam contraptions, or occasionally, on particularly cheap airships, as a means of providing propulsion. It is mostly safe to store, as it requires quite a bit of heat to start burning.

docs.title: Refined Firestone
docs.text: This black-and-red powder has many of the properties of black powder (gunpowder). It burns at a rapid rate, and if compressed, produces quite a powerful explosion. Unlike gunpowder, however, it needs no oxidizer, and will explode or catch fire even underwater. Barrels of refined firestone are almost always non-sparking metal, not wood, and are kept very carefully to prevent disaster, as an errant spark or flame could send the whole barrel up quite energetically.

docs.title: Above the table note
docs.text:
First of all, you'll note that this setting's name has been used by Matt Colville before. In short, neither of us, in this case, are particularly imaginative. Arcadia, as a name for a place, is recorded as far back as the 3rd century BCE by the ancient Greeks. The names are an unfortunate collision, but it's far too late for me to change it now, it's forever Arcadia to me. My Arcadia setting is a riff of numerous ideas and themes stolen from several pieces of media, but most strongly, Skies of Arcadia, a JRPG released for the Dreamcast in 2000, and republished for the Gamecube in 2002. Further inspirations are listed at the bottom of the page.

This setting was first played in late 2019, in a DND5e game that would last until early 2022, and the system I built the setting for was a strong influence in the worldbuilding and structure of the world. Moving to Draw Steel has not been entirely without issue.

docs.title: Locations and Elements
docs.text:
5e has ten "elemental" damage types - Acid, Lightning, Poison, Force, Fire, Ice, Necrotic, Radiant, Thunder, and Psychic. Each of these types became a continent in the initial design. Draw steel has only nine, leaving one of my initial continents without an equivalent. Otherwise, the damage types are the same, or reasonably equivalent (Radiant->Holy, Necrotic->Corruption)

Xelsoan, the continent previously associated with Force damage had no obvious equivalent. The lore of the location already had a connection to gravity and manipulation of fundamental forces, so Xelsoan loses it's "damage type", but keeps the flavor.

docs.title: People
docs.text:
Several "races" do not have equivalent "ancestries". In particular, Tabaxi, which were fairly prominent in the initial game. Tabaxi - Catfolk will remain in the setting. If a player desires to play one, we'll find some homebrew and make it work.

The flavor of various ancestries in Draw Steel has also changed to better fit this setting as I had imagined it. Most notably, Polder are not as integrated into human society as indicated in the book (but instead with Dwarves), and Revenants have a second way to come into being, a ritual perfected by the high elves of Thellonde that creates a Deathless.

docs.title: Previous Events
docs.text: The 100-hours war was the climax of the long campaign where this setting was first used. the players confronted an Elder Brain in the Hollows, ending it's plans for world domination.

docs.text:

  • Stormlight Archives book series, and in general, the cosmology of the Cosmere setting by Brandon Sanderson
